metadata.case_name: Pursa Ltd. v. Income Tax Authorities

facts.text: Pursa Ltd. incorporated in 1905 under Indian Companies Act, all shareholders and directors residents in United Kingdom, business of growing sugarcane, manufacturing sugar and dealing in sugar.
Crushing season for manufacture of sugar is from December to April each year.
Towards end of 1942, attempt made to sell entire business but failed.
In middle of 1943, directors commenced negotiations for sale of factory and other assets with ultimate object of winding up the company.
On 9th August 1943, inventory prepared and firm offer received from Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. for purchase of factory and stores as on that date.
On 16th August 1943, offer communicated by cable to directors in England.
On 20th August 1943, directors asked local managers in India to proceed with matter in anticipation of sanction of shareholders at extraordinary general meeting to be held shortly.
Extraordinary general meeting held on 8th October 1943, firm offer of Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. accepted and concluded agreement for sale came into existence.

On 7th December 1943, written memorandum of agreement executed whereby company agreed to sell to Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. for Rs. 28 lacs all lands, buildings, machinery, plant etc. as on 9th August 1943 subject to subsequent use and consumption in ordinary course of business, excluding stocks of manufactured sugar (Rs. 6 lacs) and grain, and stores bought after that date.
Dalmia Jain Company Ltd. paid Rs. 28 lacs on 7th December 1943 and got possession of factory on 10th December 1943.
Sugar stock valued at Rs. 6 lacs excluded from sale, continued to be sold by company up to June 1944 through exclusive selling agents under contract.

Between 9th August 1943 and 10th December 1943, company never used machinery and plant for manufacturing sugar or any other purpose except keeping in trim and running order; throughout accounting period (1st October 1943 to 30th September 1944) machinery and plant not used.
Company went into voluntary liquidation on 20th June 1945, delay due to legal difficulties with transfer of mokarari lands.
Assessment proceedings for assessment year 1945-46 (accounting year 1st October 1943 to 30th September 1944), liquidators represented company.
Income-tax Officer letter dated 21st February 1947 to liquidators questioning if activities were realisation of assets on impending liquidation rather than carrying on business.
Liquidators reply dated 19th March 1947: company in liquidation from 20th June 1945, disagree that not carrying on business in 1944, debits incurred in carrying on business.
Income-tax Officer letter dated 17th May 1947 claiming profits on sale of machinery and plant taxable under second proviso to section 10(2)(vii), asks to retain funds.
Liquidators reply dated 22nd May 1947: profits not taxable as not arising from business carried on but from ceasing to carry on business.
Income-tax Officer order dated 21st June 1947: profits of Rs. 13,05,144 on sale of machinery and plant liable under section 10(2)(vii), added to profits.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed appeal on 30th January 1947? (text says 1947, likely 1948).
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dismissed appeal by order dated 17th May 1949 in I.T.A. No. 147 of 1948-49.
Tribunal referred two questions under section 66(1): (1) Surplus Rs. 13,05,144 on sale of plant/machinery chargeable under s.10(2)(vii)? (2) Profit Rs.15,882 on sale of stores taxable?

Patna High Court: Shearer J. negative to both; Sarjoo Prasad J. affirmative to both; Ramaswami J. agrees with Sarjoo Prasad on first, Shearer on second. Majority: first affirmative (against assessee), second negative.
High Court declined certificate for appeal, Supreme Court granted special leave.
Department did not appeal High Court decision on second question.

legal_issues.text: On the facts and in the circumstances of this case is the surplus of Rs. 13,05,144 arising out of the sale of the plant and machinery of the sugar factory chargeable under section 10(2)(vii)?
Was the profit of Rs. 15,882 on the sale of stores of the factory taxable under the Income-tax Act in the circumstances of this case?

petitioner_arguments.text: Profits on sale of machinery and plant were not profits arising from a business carried on by the company but were profits arising from the company ceasing to carry on business.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 10(1) requires profits of business carried on

petitioner_arguments.text: Company had gone into liquidation on 20th June 1945 and was carrying on business during the year ended 30th September 1944, with debits incurred in carrying on business.

respondent_arguments.text: Company's activities during previous year might be treated as amounting to a realisation of assets on impending liquidation rather than carrying on of business.
Large profits on sale of machinery and plant taxable under second proviso to section 10(2)(vii).
Company carrying on business up to date of sale (7th December 1943), sale of machinery part of carrying on business; continued selling sugar stocks after sale with expenses, so business continued.

court_reasoning.text: Tax payable under s.10(1) only on profits of business carried on by assessee; business implies continuous exercise of activity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fundamental idea is continuous exercise of activity (citing Shaw Wallace).

court_reasoning.text: Second proviso to s.10(2)(vii) deems excess of sale proceeds over written down value as profits only for machinery/plant used for purposes of the business; 'used' means for enabling owner to carry on business and earn profits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Machinery must be used at least for part of accounting year.

court_reasoning.text: Machinery and plant not used at all during accounting year, so no allowance under clause (vii) and proviso not applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plainly in evidence, overlooked by tribunal.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal misdirected itself on meaning of s.10; findings of fact inconsistent or no evidence, open to review.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sale not part of business if invoking proviso fiction; inconsistent with tribunal's own basis.

court_reasoning.text: Admission of carrying business up to sale date consistent with selling sugar stock only, not manufacturing using machinery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No sugar manufactured in accounting year.

holdings.text: Surplus of Rs. 13,05,144 on sale of plant and machinery not chargeable under section 10(2)(vii) as machinery not used for purposes of business in accounting year.

precedents_cited.relevance: Fundamental idea of business is continuous exercise of activity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Fraser
precedents_cited.relevance: Court can intervene if tribunal misunderstands statutory language or findings unsupported by evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Tax on profits of business carried on; allowances including depreciation and balancing charge on machinery used in business; reference to High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal on the first question, holding that the surplus from sale of plant and machinery is not chargeable under section 10(2)(vii) as the assets were not used in the accounting year; second question not appealed.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed in favour of assessee on first question

key_quotes.text: "the fundamental idea underlying each of these words is the continuous exercise of an activity and the same central idea is implicit in the words 'carried on by him'"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines essence of 'business carried on' under s.10(1)

key_quotes.text: "the machinery or plant must be such as were used... at least for a part of the accounting year."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Condition for applicability of s.10(2)(vii) proviso

key_quotes.text: "the entire decision of the tribunal was vitiated by its failure to keep in view the true meaning and scope of section 10(2)(vii)"
key_quotes.speaker: court
